messages.content: How did the German enigma machine work?
The German Enigma was a type of encryption machine that was used during World War II. It was considered to be unbreakable by the Germans, but was later decoded by British code-breakers.
Right but mechanically, how did it actually work? Explain the mechanism to me.

The Enigma machine had three key components.
The first key component was the rotor.
The rotor was a metal cylinder that had 26 individual electrical circuits.
Each circuit could be set to represent a letter of the alphabet.
The first circuit was always set to the letter A.
The second circuit was always set to the letter B.
The third circuit was always set to the letter C.
All of the remaining circuits could be set to any letter.
Each time a letter was typed, the Enigma machine would first send the typed letter to the first circuit, then to the second circuit, and so on.
The second key component was the plugboard.
The plugboard was a mechanism that allowed the user to customize the Enigma machine by rewiring the circuits.
The third key component was the reflector.
The reflector was a mechanism that allowed the user to rotate the rotor to the left or right.
The reflector would send the typed letter through the rotor once, then send it through the rotor again once more.
The reflector could be set to rotate to the left or to the right.
This resulted in the letter being encrypted in two different ways, and gave the Enigma machine its unbreakable encryption.
The rotor could be set to any letter in any order.
The plugboard could be set to any letter in any order.
The reflector could be set to rotate to the left or to the right.
All of these components together made the Enigma machine very complex and extremely difficult to crack.
